reviewText:
ARMA II: Operation Arrowhead is best known for the popular zombie mod DayZ, which is a unique apocalyptic open-world experience.

But what many of the players who bought the game only to try DayZ miss out on, is the vanilla game itself and the original experience when you join an organized clan or server to teamwork with other players during tactical missions. All servers use unique player-created missions.

The missions are normally PvE, but PvP also exist to a lesser extent. Missions can range from being in an escort of military vehicles, rescue hostages, or attack/defend outposts. The game has a built-in mission editor that is easy to manage. ARMA II have plenty of realistic weapons, vehicles and characters. There are also hundreds of mods that increase the amount of everything.

The game suits people who like sandbox, simulations and action games. However, it's not a very fast-paced game like the CoD or BF-series. In the ARMA-series, you might die unless the wound is treated. You have no visible healthbar and you require a map and GPS to know where you are.

After playing this for a few years now and obtaining over 1000 hours on this game, I think it is time I reach my verdict on it. I believe that, though this game has its challenges, it is one of THE greatest games ever devised for the Personal Computer. I feel like simply doing a Pro/Con review because it's the easiest to format.

Pros
DEDICATED playing and modding community - even after being out for several years, many people, myself included still play this game religiously.

Incredible mod support - There are literally thousands of mods for this game. Hundreds of new, GIANT maps. Thousands of guns. Thousands of new unit types. Even entire overhall mods to change it into the Vietnam war or World War 2. Mods exist to change every sound in the game and graphical mods exist to ease the strain on lower end PC's or make the game more beautiful than it already was.

Already expansive game - The game, minus mod support, already contains hundreds of units, vehicles and guns in the case of Combined ops

Maps - 15km by 15km maps, enough said. Maps contain multiple towns and villages, and often 1-3 large cities and/or settlements. There are also large area with beautiful landscapes such as rocky cliffs and washing oceans.  Some custom maps can be even bigger. But to put it into perspective, Skyrim's map is about 37 square kilometers, where as the default OA Takistan map is 164 square kilometers (About 12km by 12km corner to corner). Think about that one.

Replayability - I do not mean the story when I talk about this, I talk about the virtually INFINITE ability to create scenarios in the editor. Want a tank battle 20v20? You got yourself a tank battle complete with terrain big enough to house it and FOBs for both sides. Want a small special ops team to assassinate a middle eastern dictator from 1.2 km away with a 50 cal? You got it. Want to fly an attack helicopter or CAS jet into the heat of battle? reviewText:
This review is for both Arma 2 & Arma 2: Operation Arrowhead combined. It is recommended to buy both games so you get all of the content and can join all the servers.
Arma 2 is a realistic Military Simulator. Below I will review each aspect of the game.

Aspect        Review                Gameplay        The game has very enjoyable gameplay, with many different weapons and vehicles. You can do missions, play with the editor or play on multiplayer servers with many different game modes. Even if you aren't a fan of realism, this game can still be played casually.                Graphics and Optimisation        The game is horribly optimised. Even people with top of the line PCs get around 20-40FPS at times. I personally have old hardware so cannot test the graphics properly, but at low they are still decent, but don't expect Arma 3 like graphics. The game gets extremely frustrating after a while due to the poor framerate. It should also be noted that the controls for this game are extremely uncomfortable to use, by that I mean it is unsatisfying and is the main problem I have with this game.                Additional Content        The game features some additional DLC, however not owning the DLC is no problem at all, since the light versions allow players to gain all of the content from the DLC. However, the DLC content will be low resoloution, unless you buy the DLC. The game has no microtransactions. The game can be somewhat pay to win depending on the server, as some servers offer better weapons for premium players, but this isn't every server.                Value        The game is worth the full price, as it is very enjoyable and you can get a large amount of hours out of it (for me it doesn't even get boring!). However, some people do not like the game. I recommend trying out the demo before buting the game. The game also goes on sale frequently, so it is worth waiting for that.
Aspect        Score (/10)                Gameplay        9                Graphics & Optimisation        3                Additional Content        10                Value        7                Pay to win?        No                OVERALL        8
Notes: This game is enjoyable both offline and online. It is one of the best military games I have played, but It is not to be confused with fast-paced action FPS games such as CoD. The 2 games are very different.

reviewText:
Introduction:

ArmA 2: Operation Arrowhead is the standalone DLC (Downloadable Content) Pack for ArmA 2, A Military Simulator by Czech developer Bohemia Interactive. ArmA 2: OA is the only standalone DLC pack for ArmA 2. Multiple other DLC packs play part in Takistan, Including the BAF (British Armed Forces) DLC and PMC (Private Military Contractors) DLC.

The Map(s):

ArmA 2: OA is set in the fictional Middle-Eastern country of Takistan. Takistan has many towns, villages and cities to explore, with two airfields on either end of the map. The map of Zargabad, A Small desert city in the middle of nowhere, quite small compared to Chernarus or Takistan, but the city is hugh compared to Takistan's largest, Rasman. Zargabad also comes with an airfield and a few buildings here and there. the PMC and BAF DLCs use this map as well.

The Gameplay:

ArmA 2, as a military simulator has many aspects involved in succeeding. To me, and many others, the most important is Teamwork. You have to work as a team to get things done in this game, and I love that consept. It is very slow paced, very tactical, and aimed at people that don't like to get things done rambo-style. Movement is extremely fiddly with the inability to walk through clearly enterable spaces and breaking your legs on the oddest of places. The game is fairly old, however, coming in at a 2010 release, a year after the original ArmA 2.

Graphics/Voice Acting:

Graphics and Voice Acting are quite shameful, but the game is old and developed by a Czech developer making an english game, and the quality is tolerable.

The Multiplayer:

The ArmA Multiplayer is quite easily where the most fun is to be had. With excessive mods and gamemodes developed plus the original gamemodes implemented to play with your friends, i've spent 99% of my OA Experience on the Multiplayer. My most enjoyable moments on the multiplayer moments were on Takistan Life: Revolution servers. TLR, as it is abbreviated to, is a Roleplay Mission File for OA.

My Issue(s):

My only Issue with OA is the fact that when update 1.63 was released, it wiped out an extremely large fraction of all multiplayer servers. I took this as a sign of BI telling us to go to ArmA 3, which is quite rude. Luckily, servers are popping back up here and there, which is a very good sign.

Summary:

Overall, All ArmA games are amazing in my opinion, but ArmA 2: OA gets the cake. Congratulations to Bohemia Interactive for making such an enjoyable, but serious game and I hope this review was found helpful.

Overall rating: 9.5 out of 10 / 4.5 out of 5.

Arma 2: CO is a fun military shooter while being realistic but not too realistic if you get what I mean.

reviewText:
Turned out to be one of my all-time favorites. Operation Arrowhead patches so many bugs of the basic Arma II and essentially makes it a new game.

While the game is still riddled with flaws, it is just awesome. A fantastic tool for tactical war-sim gameplay if you're so inclined and you bring a bit of brain matter into the equation.

Grab your friends and roll in a tank, build up an outpost, dominate a crowd of kids in a plane or ditch the whole public domain, install ACE and ACRE, find a platoon and immerse in tactical infantry gameplay the way you did when you were still in boot camp many moons ago.
Be a leet sniper and parachute into the action in hopes of quickscope headshots just to get mauled by enemy fire every two minutes or learn about the range of firearms and proper range estimation and use camouflage to your advantage as you work your way from one objective to the next under the cover of friendly surveillance.
Shout into Voice-Over-Net because mommy doesn't understand you or join an ACRE server, learn about the use of radios and broadcast your grid reference to your platoon commander on VHF, over.
The choices are yours to make once you realize that no two servers are the same and you don't actually have to play with toddlers.

I will love this game forever and for always.

reviewText: This is a review for the series in its totality. ARMA II and its expansions were a welcomed breath of fresh air to mainstream FPS/TPS games. Everything about this game is military ops to the letter. Real Time, Open world combat where one wrong step over a ridge can end you up flatlined. Tactical thinking is requierd in most situations on the campaigns, and sometimes even micro/macro management of your forces. Be aware that even though this game is kind of getting long in the whiskers, setting your visual settings to all high and max draw distance is not advised. The max draw distance of 10,000 (meters) will crunch even the best of Graphics card, and you will notice and performance drop. Every building in the game is descrutible (from what I have experienced). Also there are some bugs with ARMA II base game. They include, but are not limited to weapons/gear disappearing when exiting water, vehicles not spawning in when you buy them, AI getting vehicles stuck for no good reason or not properly moving to a waypoint, and in certain situtaions, losing command of certain purchased units, notably in your squad. Despite these flaws, ARMA II is still and fun and challenging series. And the multiplayer has loads of fun as well. Everything from testing weapons, to dropping a bomb on a group of civillians and watching them go sky high while your frames drop to the teens.

reviewText: This is a review for the series in its totality. ARMA II and its expansions were a welcomed breath of fresh air to mainstream FPS/TPS games. Everything about this game is military ops to the letter. Real Time, Open world combat where one wrong step over a ridge can end you up flatlined. Tactical thinking is requierd in most situations on the campaigns, and sometimes even micro/macro management of your forces. Be aware that even though this game is kind of getting long in the whiskers, setting your visual settings to all high and max draw distance is not advised. The max draw distance of 10,000 (meters) will crunch even the best of Graphics card, and you will notice and performance drop. Every building in the game is descrutible (from what I have experienced). Also there are some bugs with ARMA II base game. They include, but are not limited to weapons/gear disappearing when exiting water, vehicles not spawning in when you buy them, AI getting vehicles stuck for no good reason or not properly moving to a waypoint, and in certain situtaions, losing command of certain purchased units, notably in your squad. Despite these flaws, ARMA II is still and fun and challenging series. And the multiplayer has loads of fun as well. Everything from testing weapons, to dropping a bomb on a group of civillians and watching them go sky high while your frames drop to the teens.

No persistent loot, so you cannot just server hop.

Friendly people are everywhere.

Great game to chew up hours of free time. Play almost 100 hours and I will never regret those hours spent playing the  DayZ mod optional with the game, which I encourage you to try. Look up popularly known Youtube content creators like JackFrags, FRANKIEonPCin1080p (I know he had a couple of scandals regarding the hacking incidents, such a shame) and PsiSyndicate.

Fantastic game DayZ is.

Although a bit more expense required to play this game compared to other survival games (Rust, Romero's Aftermath and Minecraft etc.) it is still worth a buy. I bought the package with most of the DLC (ArmA 2: Complete Collection, costing $39.99 USD without any sale) making the game look fantastic. Runs extremely well on Windows 7 - 10.

There is a deep aspect of survival in this game, making it one of the most realistic zombie post-apocalyptic games on Steam. Heavily refined over the years, Arma 2: DayZ Mod is a fantastic game to play. Great fun with friends and can get lonely playing solo in the in the zombie apocalypse.

Does require deep concetration and skill to maximize enjoyment.

Spent about 90% of my playtime for this game on the Dayz mod, the rest on the editor (gotta learn to fly them choppers, right?) and on Wasteland.

I was pretty late to the party on this one, but was happy to discover the community for its mods is still up and kicking, with plenty of servers available and updates every now and then. In all honesty, I've had a blast regardless of the few glitches and bugs I've encountered, the wonky optimisation (or lack of it, if you have an AMD processor you're in for a world of hurt) and the occasional 9 year old with an unhealthy obsession with the TAB key.

At the start I focused on lonewolfing my way through but, as expected, it's when you team up that this type of experience is enhanced and my greatest highlights always involve the people I've met and befriended while trying to survive, one dead goat at a time.

Also, reloading a hatchet is hilarious. Whoever says the opposite is not someone you can trust.

ArmA II: OA is a great game which when put together with ArmA II to make ArmA II: Combined Operations can cover all the weaknesses OA had when compared to ArmA II.

Though the game takes a bit of dedication to get comfortable with, once you get used to the control system it has a massive amount to offer. Apart from the games vanilla mechanics is the massive modding community surrounding ArmA II. These can change the game in massive ways as well as add to them. Everything from DayZ, a zombie survival, to ACE, Adding new sounds, items, vehicles and mechanics to increase the realism and plausibility of game mechanics, such as first aid.

After experiencing the vanilla game and maybe a modded version which is all multiplayer friendly with servers scailing over 100 slots which run smooth, you can go into the games editor which allows you to create fully scripted missions with or without mods, with a user friendly interface that lets you make simple missions, test them and make them instantly multiplayer.

I would recommend this game to anyone who likes simulators or squad based shooters, though it would depend on how comfortable with mouse and keyboard they are as a gamepad just wont work with this. make sure to pick it up in a sale as you can buy ArmA II and ArmA II: OA which gives you content from both in one, for a stupidly cheap price for a game which you can easily spend hundreds of hours on.

reviewText:
ARMA II is a spectacular mil-sim that's all about tactics and strategy, running and gunning won't get you far here. This game features a wide variety of firearms, big and small, as well as vehicles and aircaft that can really change the tide of battle. ARMA focuses on representing it's wide assortment of toys accurately, you will find a level of detail here that is uncommon in most other shooters. That being said, it does not achieve full simulation of most things. You could probably find more accurate car characteristics in a racing game, and better aircraft simulation in a dedicated flight-sim game. It doesn't matter though, the combines arms feeling this game creates will make you feel like you're in a real battlefield.

If there was one thing I had to complain about, it would have to be the 'feel' of moving and aiming. To me, everything feels very clunky and tougher than it should be.

If you like a tactical experience of a battlefield, get this game. It really shines, in a small squad with your friends breaching a house, or in a huge battle in a city, this game is great for all aspects of war.

My recommendation: Join/host a game of domination or insurgency with a group of friends, both are very fun experiences that my buddies and I couldn't stop playing for hours.

Had the best multiplayer experience with this game a few years ago.

I was hopping through servers when I chanced upon a SERIOUS server. As soon as I logged in, a guy told me to immediately head to the chopper and I will be briefed while in the air. When the chopper took off, the mission details were given to us through voice chat. I was assigned to the sniper group and was told to follow the point man.

The helicopter dropped our group off a hill near the target location. Drop off was fast, as soon as the last person from our group got off, the chopper immediately lifted off to take other teams to their designated position.

So we were there by the hill watching the other group enter the target area through our scopes. I can hear people coordinating through voice chat, barking orders in hushed tones.

I was there watching from afar as they slowly sweep through the area. The air was tense and I tried my best to stay vigilant watching out for any hostiles.

After a while of this. We were informed that the mission was a success. Turns out there were no hostiles in the area but the mission objective (To clear the area) was a success.

It may seem like an uneventful mission. But I was at the edge of my seat the whole time.

Good times.

reviewText:
I am literally in LOVE with this game.
Arma is one of the very few games that has managed to suck out 200+ hours out of me, without me getting bored of the content within game. It is an amazing game that you should have at least tried if you are a gamer, I mean c'mon the Multiplayer of Arma II is free, and the best parts of the game are in the multiplayer!

Arma 2 OA is a standalone expansion from Arma 2 and it offers a completely new experience to the other game with a whole new upgrade to the look and feel of the game which is worth the full title cost. It is set in the fictional country of Takistan which is torn apart by the OpFor forces stationed there and is trying to be recovered by the BluFor forces stationed three. The game also allows the player to play in the old map Chernarus, but only if you own a copy of Arma II or have the Arma II Free game installed.

The single player gives you the experience of being there and commanding a unit. The single player also features parts where you are in control of your superiors and takes a different direction of how a mission is played. What it does is it gives you and objective, guidelines, but you don‚Äôt necessarily have to follow them, but for the sake of story and depth its best to play within reason. The game allows you to learn from your mistakes, adapt or play in way that nobody else has, For example I was in a mission where all my men died, and I had one injured man left, and I had to get to a rendezvous but we had to face about a chalk of men. From constantly dying in the mission, I learnt that I could not protect my teammate as he would die instantly from any damage, so instead of facing the enemy I ran off and took a stealth route, which I could complete but because of AI Intelligence, he couldn't. And it‚Äôs because of moments like that, that make the single player something really special.

The multiplayer gives you an experience of user created gameplay that very few games allow you to do, and this is one of the trademarks of the series. With some game modes and missions that you can play together with others, most people prefer to play user generated missions or game modes. The mission side of things is very simple. You get given tools that with a basic knowledge of google search or scripting allow you to create a mission that could be put in the single player of the game itself. I myself have made a few of these types of missions, ranging from border patrols, races to a vehicle and weapon showcase created to test out all the vehicles and weapons in the game and enable anyone to learn how to fly a plane or helicopter in game, without getting yelled at for wasting a valuable asset in certain multiplayer game modes.

Game modes made by independent developers or groups of people is where the main fan base of the game stands at. Some of these 'gems' include:

-Domination, a team based game where you are part of an army working together fighting and liberating towns from the OpFor stationed in them.

-DayZ which now has evolved into a standalone game, is a whole new game mode in which you are one of the many survivors of a zombie infestation and you try to live within that scenario getting over the many obstacles that would exist including in depth problems like health and blood loss and social problems like gangs bandits and trust.

-I44 is a whole re-branding of the game. It‚Äôs called Invasion 1944 and is set during the invasion of American Troops into Europe. The whole game is remade with a WW2 feel, with iconic weapons, gear clothing and vehicles. You have at your disposal, the German, British and American army to play with playing historical battles or some of the user-Generated games modes within Arma II such as DayZ and Domination.

-ACE Is an upgrade to the already semi realistic game that Arma is. It offers more depth, challenge and realism and is seen as a mod for the more hard core fans, or people that like a more difficult game or a more enhancing experience in comparison to the vanilla version. It achieves this by adding little details everywhere such as fainting and ear protection from explosions. Also it adds more difficulty with things like shooting and stamina making the game that one step more realistic.

-WasteLand is a scavenge and co-operate game mode in which players must earn money to make and but defences for their team, with a goal of domination and annihilation of the other team and the land around.

The last game mode I want to talk about RP civilian life or as it‚Äôs now known as 'RPG Life'. This game mode adds a Sims like aspect to the game, as you play a civilian who can live his life normally or he can become a criminal or rebel and fight the police force who are in charge of keeping peace in the country. With trading, working and doing normal things like eating and drinking this game mode is one that will never be the same twice.

Now this isn‚Äôt a full review of the game so I'll stop at the game modes and not expand any further as I could go on forever, talking about this game. So in short I give this game a 85/100, the reasons?
Some Positives:
-Has a decent campaign with a whole new approach to how a mission can be done
-The multiplayer is and unlimited canvas with almost unlimited potential.
-The community is a wide and strong one adding a lot to the game itself.
-The Semi-Realism is an enhancing experience that adds on a lot to the game.

Some Negatives:
-There are a lot of fundamental ideas that are expected to be seen in sandboxes that are missing.
-There could have been a lot more things done by the developers than just leaving the community to handle it and where there was support it was usually not in the places needed
-There are some really bad flaws in AI and horrible animations that really take away from the game

reviewText:
ARMA II is a spectacular mil-sim that's all about tactics and strategy, running and gunning won't get you far here. This game features a wide variety of firearms, big and small, as well as vehicles and aircaft that can really change the tide of battle. ARMA focuses on representing it's wide assortment of toys accurately, you will find a level of detail here that is uncommon in most other shooters. That being said, it does not achieve full simulation of most things. You could probably find more accurate car characteristics in a racing game, and better aircraft simulation in a dedicated flight-sim game. It doesn't matter though, the combines arms feeling this game creates will make you feel like you're in a real battlefield.

If there was one thing I had to complain about, it would have to be the 'feel' of moving and aiming. To me, everything feels very clunky and tougher than it should be.

If you like a tactical experience of a battlefield, get this game. It really shines, in a small squad with your friends breaching a house, or in a huge battle in a city, this game is great for all aspects of war.

My recommendation: Join/host a game of domination or insurgency with a group of friends, both are very fun experiences that my buddies and I couldn't stop playing for hours.

reviewText:
ArmA II: OA is a great game which when put together with ArmA II to make ArmA II: Combined Operations can cover all the weaknesses OA had when compared to ArmA II.

Though the game takes a bit of dedication to get comfortable with, once you get used to the control system it has a massive amount to offer. It has a massive choice of weapons, vehicles and troops, along with having Combined Operations you have access to two massive maps (Takistan 164 km2 and Chernarus is 225 km2), one desert and one in a forested country.

Apart from the games vanilla mechanics is the massive modding community surrounding ArmA II. These can change the game in massive ways as well as add to them. Everything from DayZ, a zombie survival, to ACE, Adding new sounds, items, vehicles and mechanics to increase the realism and plausibility of game mechanics, such as first aid.

After experiencing the vanilla game and maybe a modded version which is all multiplayer friendly with servers scailing over 100 slots which run smooth, you can go into the games editor which allows you to create fully scripted missions with or without mods, with a user friendly interface that lets you make simple missions, test them and make them instantly multiplayer.

I would recommend this game to anyone who likes simulators or squad based shooters, though it would depend on how comfortable with mouse and keyboard they are as a gamepad just wont work with this. make sure to pick it up in a sale as you can buy ArmA II and ArmA II: OA which gives you content from both in one, for a stupidly cheap price for a game which you can easily spend hundreds of hours on.

reviewText:
One of the reasons to why i built myself a computer, was that Arma 2 was only available on PC. Arma II Operation Arrowhead is what i would describe as the best Mil Sim that is commerically available. Released in 2010, Operation Arrowhead expanded the features of Arma II and enhanced the game a lot. Instead of playing in Chernarus, a new map, Takistan was introduced to the Mix. A combination of Dunes, Settlements and Airbases is what made this map special for me. Honestly, Most of my time was spent on the mission editior, just making new scenarios for my friends when we would play multiplayer. You have to have a basic understanding of programming in order to make Fluid and Fun mission, as the Mission editor does not hold your hand, it throws you out into the big world, where you either consult forums or learn by trial and error. In regards to gameplay, the game feels right, the game world can be very dynamic. Vehicals and Weapons is what really makes the game here. There are over 300 weapons (including Variations) and 80 Vehicles. The Vehicles handle nicely, and weapons feel authentic, except for the gunfire sounds. Squad interaction and Commanding is a big thing in the game, and it works very well, the AI will move stealthily, hide, and ambush on your command. Moving on, The Graphics are nothing spectacular, but they are not bad either, mostly the textures and lighting are a bit dodgy. Another problem is that the game is not very well optimised, so AA and ATOC will drop your frame rate by a lot unless you have a high end card. Apart from those issues, the graphics are okay. There is a campaign in the game, however, it is seldom played through to my knowledge. But the campaign is solid, nothing special to it, and not to forget that the voice acting is quite frankly, terrible. Finally, the main reason to why people love this game, is the Multiplayer. Servers can handle up to 100+ players, and many of these servers often have an emphasis on millitary simulation, so you have the full package; Real tactics, Radio Chatter, and team play. The multiplayer world is also a bit unforgiving, as it can happen that you play for 20 minutes and not encounter a single enemy, and as soon as you encounter your eney, he kills you in one shot. well, such is warfare. I recommend this game to millitary enthusiats and people who want to play a realistic team based game

Gameplay: 9/10
Campaign: 5/10
Graphics:   6/10
Multiplayer: 10/10

P.S

There are thousands of mods for this game

reviewText:
One of the reasons to why i built myself a computer, was that Arma 2 was only available on PC. Arma II Operation Arrowhead is what i would describe as the best Mil Sim that is commerically available. Released in 2010, Operation Arrowhead expanded the features of Arma II and enhanced the game a lot. Instead of playing in Chernarus, a new map, Takistan was introduced to the Mix. A combination of Dunes, Settlements and Airbases is what made this map special for me. Honestly, Most of my time was spent on the mission editior, just making new scenarios for my friends when we would play multiplayer. You have to have a basic understanding of programming in order to make Fluid and Fun mission, as the Mission editor does not hold your hand, it throws you out into the big world, where you either consult forums or learn by trial and error. In regards to gameplay, the game feels right, the game world can be very dynamic. Vehicals and Weapons is what really makes the game here. There are over 300 weapons (including Variations) and 80 Vehicles. The Vehicles handle nicely, and weapons feel authentic, except for the gunfire sounds. Squad interaction and Commanding is a big thing in the game, and it works very well, the AI will move stealthily, hide, and ambush on your command. Moving on, The Graphics are nothing spectacular, but they are not bad either, mostly the textures and lighting are a bit dodgy. Another problem is that the game is not very well optimised, so AA and ATOC will drop your frame rate by a lot unless you have a high end card. Apart from those issues, the graphics are okay. There is a campaign in the game, however, it is seldom played through to my knowledge. But the campaign is solid, nothing special to it, and not to forget that the voice acting is quite frankly, terrible. Finally, the main reason to why people love this game, is the Multiplayer. Servers can handle up to 100+ players, and many of these servers often have an emphasis on millitary simulation, so you have the full package; Real tactics, Radio Chatter, and team play. The multiplayer world is also a bit unforgiving, as it can happen that you play for 20 minutes and not encounter a single enemy, and as soon as you encounter your eney, he kills you in one shot. well, such is warfare. I recommend this game to millitary enthusiats and people who want to play a realistic team based game

Gameplay: 9/10
Campaign: 5/10
Graphics:   6/10
Multiplayer: 10/10

P.S

There are thousands of mods for this game

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by my low playtime. Most of my time playing has been through mod launchers that didn't include steam overlay. My actual time played is likely between 500 and 1,000 hours.

I can't recommend the base game without mods because I've never played the base game without mods. ACE and ACRE on a multiplayer server are what make the game amazing, and I don't think it's worth your time to play the single player game unmodded.

Arma II is riddled with bugs and problems. It's an incredibly demanding game, even on modern machines. It hogs your CPU and can crash for literally no reason at all. If you're playing with other people (as you should) you'll likely spend hours standing around doing nothing, then get shot in the first few seconds of a firefight and spend the next five minutes staring at a black screen until the death screen pops up because you bled out.

You'll drive down a dirt road at a snails pace watching for IEDs, only to get blown up by one you didn't see hidden in a bush. Then you'll drive down the same road, again, and when you arrive at you area of operation you'll take a bullet to the head and die instantly.

Sometimes you'll have to sit around on a hilltop looking at enemies for 30 minutes while you wait for your fireteam leader to radio the squad leader, who then has to radio command, who then has to radio back questions, which are relayed to your fireteam leader, who answer them back to the squad leader, who radios back to command, who radios back to squad leader permission to engage, who sends back to your fireteam leader, who then tells you you can engage. And that's if everyone is listening to each other. More likely you'll sit around for thirty minutes while the fireteam leader tries to contact the squad leader who doesn't even have their radio on.

Occasionally you'll gear up for a halo jump or fastrope operation, gather everyone on the tarmac, load up into the helicopter, wait for the pilot to discuss drop zone with your officers, then after fifteen minutes of flying your screen will go black with the sound of a surface to air missle blowing a hole through the cockpit.

Believe me when I say Arma II has been the most fun and engaging video game I've ever played and if I could only have one game for the rest of my life it would be this.

reviewText: Arma 2 OA is a great game all around. It's a bit buggy, and the graphics are not exactly stunning, but it is realistic and fun, if you know where to look. The Level Editor is fun to mess around with (think 500 vehicles and helis and planes fighting in a desert filled with chickens) and the single missions (scenarios) contain lots of content, too. The campaigns are lengthy and are diverse. Downloadable content is available, adding even more replayability. Of course, you can't forget that the DayZ Mod requires Arma 2 and Arma 2 OA. The multiplayer is largely unused, since DayZ is what the large majority of the players do with Arma 2. I would highly recommend this to anyone with any sort of FPS interests, and especially if you are interested in zombies games, due to the DayZ mod
